articles.headline: For Some Minority-Owned Businesses, Their Lenders Are Now Their Defenders
articles.snippet: Black- and Latino-owned businesses have suffered damage from vandals and arsonists on the fringes of the protests over police brutality. Non-bank community lenders are out to protect them.
articles.abstract: Black- and Latino-owned businesses have suffered damage from vandals and arsonists on the fringes of the protests over police brutality. Non-bank community lenders are out to protect them.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening in Ferguson, Mo., a dozen people formed a human chain around Reds The One and Only BBQ, a restaurant. Vandals had smashed other storefronts in the area amid protests over the killing of George Floyd in police custody, but Reds was still standing.

articles.headline: At George Floyd Memorial, an Anguished Call for Change
articles.snippet: Flanked by the family of Mr. Floyd, the Rev. Al Sharpton said, “It’s time to stand up and say, ‘Get your knee off our necks.’”
articles.abstract: Flanked by the family of Mr. Floyd, the Rev. Al Sharpton said, “It’s time to stand up and say, ‘Get your knee off our necks.’”
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Hundreds of people filed into a Minneapolis chapel on Thursday to remember George Floyd, the man whose death at the hands of the police opened a nationwide flood of anguish, protest and demands for change in American policing.

articles.headline: Trump and the Military: A Mutual Embrace Might Dissolve on America’s Streets
articles.snippet: “There is a thin line between the military’s tolerance for questionable partisan moves over the past three years and the point where these become intolerable,” a retired general said.
articles.abstract: “There is a thin line between the military’s tolerance for questionable partisan moves over the past three years and the point where these become intolerable,” a retired general said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the first three years of President Trump’s time in office, his blunt-force view of the military was confined to threatening American adversaries: “fire and fury” if North Korea challenged American troops. A warning that he would “shoot down and destroy” Iranian forces in the Persian Gulf. Billions spent to rejuvenate a nuclear arsenal he viewed as the ultimate source of American power.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Why Some Democrats Worry About the Whiteness of Biden’s Inner Circle
articles.snippet: Even as his team adds people of color, allies worry that a lack of diverse viewpoints at the top could come with a steep cost: the possibility of taking for granted his strength with black voters.
articles.abstract: Even as his team adds people of color, allies worry that a lack of diverse viewpoints at the top could come with a steep cost: the possibility of taking for granted his strength with black voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly five years ago, Joseph R. Biden Jr. gathered his closest advisers to decide whether he would run for president in 2016. This was a “final judgment” meeting, as he would later describe it in his memoir, and around the room were Mr. Biden’s family and more than a half-dozen of his most trusted confidantes.

articles.headline: Rare Stock Tweak During Pandemic Adds Millions to a C.E.O.’s Potential Payout
articles.snippet: Raytheon Technologies, the defense contractor, reset the stock price it would use to calculate certain compensation for its chief and other employees.
articles.abstract: Raytheon Technologies, the defense contractor, reset the stock price it would use to calculate certain compensation for its chief and other employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Raytheon Technologies, one of the country’s biggest defense contractors, recently cut salaries for thousands of employees as the pandemic crimped business. Around the same time, it also quietly made a change to the pay package of its chief executive, Gregory J. Hayes, that could increase his future income by millions of dollars.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Anupreeta Das

articles.headline: Google’s European Search Menu Draws Interest of U.S. Antitrust Investigators
articles.snippet: To placate European regulators, the company started giving Android phone users a choice in search engines when they set up their devices.
articles.abstract: To placate European regulators, the company started giving Android phone users a choice in search engines when they set up their devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — For the last few months, some people who bought a new smartphone in Europe with Google’s Android software were presented with an extra option while setting up the device: choosing a search engine other than Google.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and David McCabe

articles.headline: Research Shows Students Falling Months Behind During Virus Disruptions
articles.snippet: The abrupt switch to remote learning wiped out academic gains for many students in America, and widened racial and economic gaps. Catching up in the fall won’t be easy.
articles.abstract: The abrupt switch to remote learning wiped out academic gains for many students in America, and widened racial and economic gaps. Catching up in the fall won’t be easy.
articles.lead_paragraph: While a nation of burned-out, involuntary home schoolers slogs to the finish line of a disrupted academic year, a picture is emerging of the extent of the learning loss among children in America, and the size of the gaps schools will be asked to fill when they reopen.

articles.headline: Tenants’ Troubles Put Stress on Commercial Real Estate
articles.snippet: As landlords face rent shortfalls and renegotiation because of the pandemic, lenders are also exposed. Hotels and retail spaces have been hit hardest.
articles.abstract: As landlords face rent shortfalls and renegotiation because of the pandemic, lenders are also exposed. Hotels and retail spaces have been hit hardest.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the middle of March, as Covid-19 was shutting down the U.S. economy, Hughes Marino, a West Coast commercial real estate brokerage firm based in San Diego, wrote an email to clients offering to haggle with their landlords for lower rent. The firm was ready to help companies “restructure their leases as rents collapse,” it said.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Brooks Bros., ‘Made in America’ Since 1818, May Soon Need a New Calling Card
articles.snippet: The clothing brand, which has dressed all but four U.S. presidents, could end up closing its three American factories as it navigates the pandemic.
articles.abstract: The clothing brand, which has dressed all but four U.S. presidents, could end up closing its three American factories as it navigates the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late March, Brooks Brothers was showered with praise after announcing it would use its three clothing factories in the United States to make personal protective equipment to help fight Covid-19.
articles.byline: By Vanessa Friedman and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: The Complex Debate Over Silicon Valley’s Embrace of Content Moderation
articles.snippet: Many in tech cheered when Twitter added labels to President Trump’s tweets. But civil libertarians caution that social media companies are moving into uncharted waters.
articles.abstract: Many in tech cheered when Twitter added labels to President Trump’s tweets. But civil libertarians caution that social media companies are moving into uncharted waters.
articles.lead_paragraph: The existential question that every big tech platform from Twitter to Google to Facebook has to wrestle with is the same: How responsible should it act for the content that people post?

articles.headline: What to Make of the Rebound in the U.S. Jobs Report
articles.snippet: Many of the gains came in restaurant work as 2.5 million jobs were added in May and the unemployment rate fell to 13.3 percent.
articles.abstract: Many of the gains came in restaurant work as 2.5 million jobs were added in May and the unemployment rate fell to 13.3 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The job market halted its pandemic-induced collapse in May as employers brought back millions of workers and the unemployment rate unexpectedly declined.
